highlights.para: The capplets in the Main area enable you to customize your desktop background and your screensaver. You can use the Main capplets to configure your default applications and your HTML viewer, and to configure your keyboard settings and mouse settings. You can also use the Main capplets to set your sound preferences and to customize your startup hints.
This chapter describes how to use the Main capplets to customize your desktop.

sect1.title: Customizing the Desktop Background
sect1.para: The desktop background is the part of the desktop where there are no interface graphical items, such as panels and windows. The desktop background is always behind the other interface items.
You can customize the desktop background in the following ways:

listitem.para: Select a color for the desktop background. You can select a solid color or create a gradient effect with two colors. A gradient effect is a visual effect where one color blends gradually into another color.

Select an image to display on the desktop background. The image is superimposed on the desktop background color. That is, the desktop background color is visible if you select a transparent image, or if the image does not cover the entire desktop background.

sect1.para: You can also change the appearance of your desktop background from within the Nautilus file manager.
To display the Background capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Desktop Background.
lists the background settings that you can configure.

para.guilabel: Use a picture for the background

entry.para: Select this option if you want to display a graphic image on your desktop background. To specify the image to display and how to display the image, use the elements in the Background picture group.

To specify an image to display, select the image from the Image drop-down combination box. Alternatively, click on the Browse button to display the Wallpaper Selection dialog. Use the Wallpaper Selection dialog to find the graphic file that you want to display on the desktop background.
To specify how to display the image, select one of the following options from the Style drop-down list box:

listitem.para: Tiled: Repeats the image to cover the desktop background.
Centered: Displays the image in the middle of the desktop background.
Scaled (keep aspect) : Enlarges the image until the image meets the screen edges, and maintains the relative dimensions of the image.
Scaled: Enlarges the image to cover the desktop background, and does not maintain the relative dimensions of the image.
Embossed Logo: Places an embossed version of the image in the bottom right corner of the desktop background. This option works only with JPEG format images.

entry.para: Use this group to specify the color scheme for the desktop background. To specify the color scheme, you use a combination of the options in the Style drop-down list box, and the color selector buttons.
You can specify a color scheme in one of the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Solid from the Style drop-down list box to specify a single color as the desktop background.
To choose the color that you require, click on the first color selector button on the right side of the drop-down list box to display the Pick a Color dialog. Choose a color, then click OK.
Choose Horizontal Gradient from the Style drop-down list box to create a gradient effect from one horizontal screen edge to the other horizontal screen edge.
Click on the first color selector button on the right side of the drop-down list box to display the Pick a Color dialog. Choose the color that you want to appear at the top horizontal edge.
Click on the second color selector button on the right side of the drop-down list box to display the Pick a Color dialog. Choose the color that you want to appear at the bottom horizontal edge.
Choose Vertical Gradient from the Style drop-down list box to create a gradient effect from one vertical screen edge to the other vertical screen edge.
Click on the first color selector button on the right side of the drop-down list box to display the Pick a Color dialog. Choose the color that you want to appear at the left vertical edge.
Click on the second color selector button on the right side of the drop-down list box to display the Pick a Color dialog. Choose the color that you want to appear at the right vertical edge.

sect1.title: Choosing Default Applications
sect1.para: Use the Default Editor capplet to associate an editor application with the gnome-edit command. You can choose from a drop-down list of windowed and non-windowed editing applications. Windowed applications are those programs that run in their own frame on your desktop. Windowed applications have a graphical user interface which you use to interact with the program. Non-windowed applications run in a terminal emulator window which provides access to the UNIX shell for the program. Use typed commands to interact with a non-windowed application.
To display the Default Editor capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Document Handlers Default Editor.

sect1.para: You can customize the settings for your HTML viewer in the following functional areas:

sect2.title: Keyboard Shortcuts Functionality
sect2.para: Use the Keyboard Shortcuts tabbed section of the HTML Viewer capplet to configure the mapping of keyboard shortcuts for the default HTML viewer application. You can select one of the existing keymaps, or you can select Custom and specify your own set of keyboard shortcuts.

To display the Keyboard Shortcuts tabbed section of the HTML Viewer capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Document Handlers HTML Viewer. In the HTML Viewer dialog pane, click on the Keyboards Shortcuts tab.

sect1.title: Configuring Keyboard Settings
sect1.para: Use the keyboard capplet to specify the autorepeat settings for your keyboard, and to configure the sound events that are associated with the keyboard.
To display the Keyboard capplet, open the Main Menu, then choose Programs Settings Peripherals Keyboard.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Keyboard tabbed section on Keyboard capplet

sect1.para: lists the settings you can configure using the keyboard capplet.

entry.para: Option
Function

Select the Enable auto-repeat option to continuously enter a character when you press and hold down a key on your keyboard.
Use the Repeat rate slider to specify the number of times per second that the character is repeated.
Use the Repeat delay slider to specify the delay in milliseconds from the time a key is pressed until the character starts to repeat.
Select the Click on keypress option to activate a small click sound when you press a key on your keyboard. Use the Click volume slider to specify the volume at which the click is played.

Some applications play a bell sound to indicate a keyboard input error. Use the options in the Keyboard bell group to configure the bell sound.
Use the Volume slider to specify the volume at which the bell sound is played.
Use the Pitch slider to specify the pitch in Hertz at which the bell sound is played.
Use the Duration slider to specify the length of time in milliseconds that the bell sound lasts.
Click on the Test button to play the keyboard bell as configured.

sect1.title: Configuring Mouse Settings
sect1.para: Use the mouse capplet to configure your mouse for right or for left hand use. You can also specify the speed and sensitivity of mouse pointer movement in response to mouse movement.
To display the Mouse capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Peripherals Mouse.
lists the settings you can configure using the mouse capplet:

entry.para: Option
Function
Choose right handed or left handed mouse button configuration.

Use the options in the Mouse motion group to configure movement and sensitivity of the mouse pointer on screen relative to movements of the mouse.
Use the Acceleration slider to configure the speed at which your mouse pointer moves across your screen in response to movements of your mouse.
Use the Threshold slider to configure the sensitivity of your mouse pointer in response to movements of your mouse. If the slider is set to Small, then a small movement of the mouse is enough to invoke the Acceleration specified.

sect1.title: Customizing the Screensaver
sect1.para: You can use the Screensaver capplet to choose a screensaver from the list that is displayed, and to configure the settings.
To display the Screensaver capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Desktop Screensaver.

sect1.title: Setting Sound Preferences
sect1.para: The Sound capplet enables you to control the launch of the GNOME sound engine (ESD). You can also specify the sounds that play when events occur.
You can customize the settings for the Sound capplet in the following functional areas.

sect2.title: General Functionality
sect2.para: Use the General tabbed section of the Sound capplet to specify the launch of the GNOME sound engine, and to activate the sound event functionality.
To display the General tabbed section of the Sound capplet, open the Main Menu then choose Programs Settings Multimedia Sound.
lists the general sound settings you can configure using the Sound capplet.

entry.para: Option
Function
Select this option to launch the GNOME sound engine when you start a GNOME session. The GNOME sound engine (ESD) must be active for sound events to occur.

Select this option to activate the settings that are specified in the Sounds Events tabbed section of the sound capplet. This option can only be selected if the Enable sound server startup option is selected.

sect1.title: Customizing Startup Hint
sect1.para: The Startup Hint capplet enables you to select the type of hint or message that is displayed when you start your GNOME session.
To display the Startup Hint capplet, open the Main Menu, then choose Programs Settings Session Startup Hint.
lists the startup hint settings that you can configure.

entry.para: Option
Function

Select this option for startup hints to display when you start a GNOME session. The default setting is selected. Choose one of the following options to specify the type of hint or message that is displayed:
Display normal hints
Choose this option to display hints on how to use the GNOME desktop.
Display fortunes
Choose this option to invoke the fortune application when you start a GNOME session. This application displays a random saying or fortune.
Display message of the day
Choose this option to display a text message from a specified file when you start a GNOME session. This option can be chosen to enable your system administrator to inform you of news or system information.

entry.para: Use this field to specify the text file used if the Display message of the day option is chosen.
